elements.content: The ultimately thin single-strand gold filaments, of Au+···Au+ bonded gold­(I) diethyldithiocarbamate polymer, AuEt2DTC, can be transformed depending on pressure and solvate contents. When synthesized in the presence of CH2Cl2, it crystallizes into a tetragonal AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 phase α with ligand-supported and unsupported Au+···Au+ bonded filaments modulated into molecular Au8-pitch helices. Low contents of CH2Cl2 favors the β phase of significantly reduced volume and orthorhombic space group Fddd. The α-AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 crystal exhibits a highly unusual negative-area compressibility, due to the spring-like compression of helices. Above 0.05 GPa, the crystal transforms to phase β, where the Au16-pitch helices partly unwind their turns, which relaxes the tension generated by external pressure between neighboring helices of the opposite handedness. This is a unique observation of atomic-scale helical filaments transformation, which otherwise is a universal process analogous to the helix reversal between DNA forms B and Z, and in macroscopic world it is similar to nonperiodic unwind kinks in grapevine tendrils and telephone cords. Pressure also reduces the differences between the ligand-supported and unsupported Au+···Au+ bonds.
elements.clean_text: The ultimately thin single-strand gold filaments, of Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonded gold(I) diethyldithiocarbamate polymer, AuEt2DTC, can be transformed depending on pressure and solvate contents. When synthesized in the presence of CH2Cl2, it crystallizes into a tetragonal AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 phase α with ligand-supported and unsupported Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonded filaments modulated into molecular Au8-pitch helices. Low contents of CH2Cl2 favors the β phase of significantly reduced volume and orthorhombic space group Fddd. The α-AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 crystal exhibits a highly unusual negative-area compressibility, due to the spring-like compression of helices. Above 0.05 GPa, the crystal transforms to phase β, where the Au16-pitch helices partly unwind their turns, which relaxes the tension generated by external pressure between neighboring helices of the opposite handedness. This is a unique observation of atomic-scale helical filaments transformation, which otherwise is a universal process analogous to the helix reversal between DNA forms B and Z, and in macroscopic world it is similar to nonperiodic unwind kinks in grapevine tendrils and telephone cords. Pressure also reduces the differences between the ligand-supported and unsupported Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds.

elements.content: The supramolecular architectures of metal organic frameworks (MOF’s), two- and one-dimensional coordination polymers and metal complexes have been extensively studied due to their exceptional physical and chemical properties. These novel hybrid materials are required for various application involving gas storage and purification, catalysis, and ferroelectric switches. Noble-metals complexes are particularly intriguing due to their closed-shell metallophilic interactions, strong luminescence, and direct relevance to gold nanoparticles applied in medicine and photochemical sensors technology. Recently, high-pressure studies on metallophilic interactions in noble-metals complexes revealed that the luminescence of Au+···Au+ bonded polymers based on gold­(I) dithiocarbamates linked by oligomeric gold–gold interactions is highly piezo- and pyro-sensitive. The luminescence shifts were associated with the compressed Au+···Au+ distances and reduced HOMO–LUMO energy gap of neighboring gold­(I) centers.
elements.clean_text: The supramolecular architectures of metal organic frameworks (MOF's), two- and one-dimensional coordination polymers and metal complexes have been extensively studied due to their exceptional physical and chemical properties. These novel hybrid materials are required for various application involving gas storage and purification, catalysis, and ferroelectric switches. Noble-metals complexes are particularly intriguing due to their closed-shell metallophilic interactions, strong luminescence, and direct relevance to gold nanoparticles applied in medicine and photochemical sensors technology. Recently, high-pressure studies on metallophilic interactions in noble-metals complexes revealed that the luminescence of Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonded polymers based on gold(I) dithiocarbamates linked by oligomeric gold-gold interactions is highly piezo- and pyro-sensitive. The luminescence shifts were associated with the compressed Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ distances and reduced HOMO-LUMO energy gap of neighboring gold(I) centers.

elements.content: Here we report the pressure-induced shortening of aurophilic contacts in a gold­(I) diethyldithiocarbamate polymer AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 and conformational transformations of this single-strand gold filaments in the crystal structure. The shorter Au+···Au+ bonds, of about 2.78 Å, are ligand-supported inside the [AuEt2DTC]2 rings, and unsupported Au+···Au+ bonds outside the rings are by about 0.2 Å longer (Figure ). It is shown that its compression reduces differences between the ligand-supported and unsupported Au+···Au+ bonds. We have established that two known polymorphs of AuEt2DTC, tetragonal α-phase, space group I41/a, and orthorhombic β-phase, space group Fddd, are low- and high-pressure forms of this compound with voids partly filled by CH2Cl2 molecules. Both the polymorphs are built of [Au2(C4H10NCS2)2] monomers linked into Au+···Au+ bonded helical filaments (Figure ). The transition between phases α and β involves molecular-scale transformations of the Au+···Au+ filaments, their compression, changes of helical-modulation frequency, and unwinding snags of their turns. We found 48 reports on the structures aggregated by aurophilic bond into linear (13 reports), zigzag (21), or helical (14) chains. Numerous zero-dimensional aurophilic clusters, including Au4 squares with Au+···Au+···Au+ angles of 90°, testify that these interactions are very flexible. Below we show that the conformations of the aurophilic aggregates can be considerably affected by pressure.
elements.clean_text: Here we report the pressure-induced shortening of aurophilic contacts in a gold(I) diethyldithiocarbamate polymer AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 and conformational transformations of this single-strand gold filaments in the crystal structure. The shorter Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds, of about 2.78 Å, are ligand-supported inside the [AuEt2DTC]2 rings, and unsupported Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds outside the rings are by about 0.2 Å longer (Figure ). It is shown that its compression reduces differences between the ligand-supported and unsupported Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds. We have established that two known polymorphs of AuEt2DTC, tetragonal α-phase, space group I41/a, and orthorhombic β-phase, space group Fddd, are low- and high-pressure forms of this compound with voids partly filled by CH2Cl2 molecules. Both the polymorphs are built of [Au2(C4H10NCS2)2] monomers linked into Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonded helical filaments (Figure ). The transition between phases α and β involves molecular-scale transformations of the Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ filaments, their compression, changes of helical-modulation frequency, and unwinding snags of their turns. We found 48 reports on the structures aggregated by aurophilic bond into linear (13 reports), zigzag (21), or helical (14) chains. Numerous zero-dimensional aurophilic clusters, including Au4 squares with Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ angles of 90°, testify that these interactions are very flexible. Below we show that the conformations of the aurophilic aggregates can be considerably affected by pressure.

elements.content: Schematic structural formula of Au+···Au+ bonded filament in AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2. The curly brackets below the scheme indicate one of two identical units in phase α (red) and twice longer interval in phase β (blue), where two units of phase α are somewhat differentiated. The ligand-supported endocyclic Au+···Au+ bonds are by about 0.2 Å shorter than the exocyclic unsupported bonds. H-Atoms and solvate molecules have been omitted in this scheme.
elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic structural formula of Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonded filament in AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2. The curly brackets below the scheme indicate one of two identical units in phase α (red) and twice longer interval in phase β (blue), where two units of phase α are somewhat differentiated. The ligand-supported endocyclic Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds are by about 0.2 Å shorter than the exocyclic unsupported bonds. H-Atoms and solvate molecules have been omitted in this scheme.

elements.content: Single turns of helix-modulated Au+···Au+ bonded filaments viewed perpendicular and along their direction in phases: (a) α-AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2; (b) β-AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2. The AuEt2DTC monomer has been enclosed in brackets. The thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 30% probability level and isotropic H atoms as small spheres. The solvate molecules are omitted.
elements.clean_text: 2  Single turns of helix-modulated Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonded filaments viewed perpendicular and along their direction in phases: (a) α-AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2; (b) β-AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2. The AuEt2DTC monomer has been enclosed in brackets. The thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 30% probability level and isotropic H atoms as small spheres. The solvate molecules are omitted.

elements.content: We found that the AuEt2DTC modifications α and β can be controlled at ambient pressure by the solvent mixture used for the synthesis and crystallization. The CH2Cl2:CH3OH 1:1 mixture favors the formation of α-AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2, whereas of the solutions with a low contents of CH2Cl2, form β was obtained. It is also possible to obtain both forms together from one crystallization: initially form α precipitates, and then form β follows when the concentration of volatile CH2Cl2 is reduced in the mixture. We have associated the formation of phases α and β with the incorporation of CH2Cl2 molecules in the voids of AuEt2DTC crystals (Figure ). Our single-crystal low-temperature and high-pressure structural studies confirmed the formation of solvated AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2, where x for different samples can assume values between 0 and 1/2. The guest CH2Cl2 molecules are strongly disordered in two orientations at least, and their detection is hampered at room temperature by the adverse circumstances of strong vibrations (high atomic displacement parameters, ADP’s) and very strong scattering of X-rays by Au atoms (the electron density of other atoms is relatively low). Additionally, the AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 crystals are highly plastic and under nonhydrostatic stress (e.g., when pressed with a needle) they easily develop defects lowering the quality of single crystals. Our samples investigated at 0.1 MPa had x close to 0.25 for phase α and x of 0.12 or lower for phase β. The contents of solvate CH2Cl2 according to the crystal symmetry of these structures, for one independent site occupied in phase α is 1/4 and in phase β it is equal to 1/8, so for higher contents of CH2Cl2, several independent voids have to be occupied (cf. Figure 7 in the ). In order to elucidate the effect of solvent, we have also substituted CH2Cl2 in the solvate mixture with CH3OH by tetrahydrofuran (THF), the molecules of which are larger than the voids. The subsequent synthesis yielded exclusively the β-phase, which confirmed that the inclusions of CH2Cl2 are essential for the formation of phase α. The hydrophobic channels do not incorporate CH3OH molecules. The solvation of AuEt2DTC by CH2Cl2 at ambient conditions results in the significantly larger, by nearly 10 Å3, molecular volume (unit-cell V/Z) of phase α than that of phase β (see Figure and Tables S1 and S2 of the ).

The CH2Cl2:CH3OH 1:1 mixture favors the formation of α-AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2, whereas of the solutions with a low contents of CH2Cl2, form β was obtained. It is also possible to obtain both forms together from one crystallization: initially form α precipitates, and then form β follows when the concentration of volatile CH2Cl2 is reduced in the mixture. We have associated the formation of phases α and β with the incorporation of CH2Cl2 molecules in the voids of AuEt2DTC crystals (Figure ). Our single-crystal low-temperature and high-pressure structural studies confirmed the formation of solvated AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2, where x for different samples can assume values between 0 and 1/2. The guest CH2Cl2 molecules are strongly disordered in two orientations at least, and their detection is hampered at room temperature by the adverse circumstances of strong vibrations (high atomic displacement parameters, ADP's) and very strong scattering of X-rays by Au atoms (the electron density of other atoms is relatively low). Additionally, the AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 crystals are highly plastic and under nonhydrostatic stress (e.g., when pressed with a needle) they easily develop defects lowering the quality of single crystals. Our samples investigated at 0.1 MPa had x close to 0.25 for phase α and x of 0.12 or lower for phase β. Figure 7 in the ). elements.content: We further observed that above 50 MPa (0.05 GPa) the tetragonal crystals of α-phase transform to phase β, and that this transition is repetitively reversible, while the unsolvated orthorhombic β-phase crystals do not transform to phase α even after long time at ambient pressure, or after hydrostatic compression. The channel-like voids in AuEt2DTC have narrowings preventing transport of guest molecules to and out of the crystal. The CH2Cl2 molecules trapped in the voids are unlikely to be removed at normal conditions, and, reversely, high pressure does not push new guests into the voids. In principle, polymorphs should have the same composition. At ambient conditions, the AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 forms α and β indicate their different solvation (larger x in form α and lower in β). On the other hand, the solvate of α form can be transformed to form β of the same composition by high pressure.
elements.clean_text: We further observed that above 50 MPa (0.05 GPa) the tetragonal crystals of α-phase transform to phase β, and that this transition is repetitively reversible, while the unsolvated orthorhombic β-phase crystals do not transform to phase α even after long time at ambient pressure, or after hydrostatic compression. The channel-like voids in AuEt2DTC have narrowings preventing transport of guest molecules to and out of the crystal. The CH2Cl2 molecules trapped in the voids are unlikely to be removed at normal conditions, and, reversely, high pressure does not push new guests into the voids. In principle, polymorphs should have the same composition. At ambient conditions, the AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 forms α and β indicate their different solvation (larger x in form α and lower in β). On the other hand, the solvate of α form can be transformed to form β of the same composition by high pressure.

elements.content: In both forms α and β the Au2(C4H10NCS2)2 units polymerize into infinite Au+···Au+ bonded filaments (Figure ). We established that the crystal structures of forms α and β are closely related. Their unit-cell dimensions are correlated and have similar structures of the Au+···Au+ bonded filaments. The filaments extend along crystal direction [001], as shown in Figure , and parameter c β is approximately twice longer than c α (the indices indicate forms α and β). Likewise, parameters a α and b α are approximately halves of the diagonals of the a β b β unit-cell base. The CH2Cl2 solvate molecules “inflate” the voids of phase α. These “inflated” voids assume more spherical shape and the crystal assumes the tetragonal symmetry. Under high pressure, the voids in the square pattern of filaments located in phase α collapse and are distorted toward a rhomboid pattern of phase β (Figure ). This rhomboid pattern is also found for empty or on average nearly empty “deflated” voids of unsolvated and hardly solvated β-AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2.
elements.clean_text: In both forms α and β the Au2(C4H10NCS2)2 units polymerize into infinite Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonded filaments (Figure ). We established that the crystal structures of forms α and β are closely related. Their unit-cell dimensions are correlated and have similar structures of the Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonded filaments. The filaments extend along crystal direction [001], as shown in Figure , and parameter c β is approximately twice longer than c α (the indices indicate forms α and β). Likewise, parameters a α and b α are approximately halves of the diagonals of the a β b β unit-cell base. The CH2Cl2 solvate molecules "inflate" the voids of phase α. These "inflated" voids assume more spherical shape and the crystal assumes the tetragonal symmetry. Under high pressure, the voids in the square pattern of filaments located in phase α collapse and are distorted toward a rhomboid pattern of phase β (Figure ). This rhomboid pattern is also found for empty or on average nearly empty "deflated" voids of unsolvated and hardly solvated β-AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2.

elements.content: The crystal compression can be correlated to its structure built of Au+···Au+ bonded helices and to the collapse of channel voids. The transformation between phases α and β hardly affects the distances between the close filaments (along directions [100]α and [010]α in phase α). In phase α, these distances slightly increase with pressure along a α and b α, which leads to the negative-area compression of this phase. This effect can be compared to the increased radius of a compressed spring. The crystal discontinuous compression on the transition to phase β mainly results of collapsed voids, becoming longer along [010]β and shorter along [100]β. This indicates that the interactions between neighboring filaments are very important for the helical modulation of filaments. Owing to the similar parallel arrangement of the filaments, phase α is a prototypic ferroelastic form and phase β is its orientational state. The mechanism of collapsing voids in phase β leads to increasingly different parameters a β and b β with increasing pressure (Figure ).

In phase α, these distances slightly increase with pressure along a α and b α, which leads to the negative-area compression of this phase. This effect can be compared to the increased radius of a compressed spring. The crystal discontinuous compression on the transition to phase β mainly results of collapsed voids, becoming longer along [010]β and shorter along [100]β. This indicates that the interactions between neighboring filaments are very important for the helical modulation of filaments. Owing to the similar parallel arrangement of the filaments, phase α is a prototypic ferroelastic form and phase β is its orientational state. The mechanism of collapsing voids in phase β leads to increasingly different parameters a β and b β with increasing pressure (Figure ).

elements.content: Crystal structure of AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 viewed perpendicular to and along the Au+···Au+ filaments: (a) phase α at 296 K/0.1 MPa; (b) phase β at 296 K/0.58 GPa. The thermal ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level. The disordered CH2Cl2 molecules have been omitted for clarity (cf. Figure S7).
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure of AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 viewed perpendicular to and along the Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ filaments: (a) phase α at 296 K/0.1 MPa; (b) phase β at 296 K/0.58 GPa. The thermal ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level. The disordered CH2Cl2 molecules have been omitted for clarity (cf. Figure S7).

elements.content: Pressure dependence of the unit-cell dimensions in the AuEt2DTC phases α (open circles) and β (full circles): (a) molecular volume (V/Z); (b) unit-cell parameters. The dashed lines indicate the phase transition.
elements.clean_text: 4  Pressure dependence of the unit-cell dimensions in the AuEt2DTC phases α (open circles) and β (full circles): (a) molecular volume (V/Z); (b) unit-cell parameters. The dashed lines indicate the phase transition.

elements.content: The shorter parameter a β is considerably softer than the longer b β parameter. At still higher pressure the crystal gradually becomes more soft along [010]β; however, this direction remains the hardest in the crystal, and at 1.0 GPa the difference between a β and b β increases to nearly 2.5 Å. Intramolecular Au+···Au+ bonds within the Au2(C4H10NCS2)2 monomers of 2.77–2.78 Å are shorter than the Au+···Au+ bonds between the monomers, of 2.96–3.01 Å at ambient conditions (Figure ). In both phases the pitch of helix-modulated filaments is equal in length to the unit-cell c dimension, twice longer in phase β than in phase α (Figures and ). The strong compression of AuEt2DTC crystals along the Au+···Au+ bonded helices parallel to the [z] axis (Figure ) is the combined effect of both the compression of the Au+···Au+ bonds (Figure ) and to conformational transformations of the helices.
elements.clean_text: The shorter parameter a β is considerably softer than the longer b β parameter. At still higher pressure the crystal gradually becomes more soft along [010]β; however, this direction remains the hardest in the crystal, and at 1.0 GPa the difference between a β and b β increases to nearly 2.5 Å. Intramolecular Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds within the Au2(C4H10NCS2)2 monomers of 2.77-2.78 Å are shorter than the Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds between the monomers, of 2.96-3.01 Å at ambient conditions (Figure ). In both phases the pitch of helix-modulated filaments is equal in length to the unit-cell c dimension, twice longer in phase β than in phase α (Figures  and ). The strong compression of AuEt2DTC crystals along the Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonded helices parallel to the [z] axis (Figure ) is the combined effect of both the compression of the Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds (Figure ) and to conformational transformations of the helices.

elements.content: Compression of Au+···Au+ distances in AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 phases α (open circles) and β (full symbols): intramolecular ligand-supported bonds are shorter, and intermolecular ligand-unsupported bonds are longer. The pressure dependence of Au···Au distance (hardly changing to 1.0 GPa) metallic gold is shown as the dashed line.
elements.clean_text: 5  Compression of Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ distances in AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 phases α (open circles) and β (full symbols): intramolecular ligand-supported bonds are shorter, and intermolecular ligand-unsupported bonds are longer. The pressure dependence of Au⋅⋅⋅Au distance (hardly changing to 1.0 GPa) metallic gold is shown as the dashed line.

elements.content: The unsupported intermolecular Au+···Au+ bonds are compressed at the average rate of β­(Au+···Au+) = (1/d)­(Δd/Δp) equal to −0.1006 GPa–1. The average compressibility β­(Au···Au) of intramolecular ligands-supported Au+···Au+ bonds, measured between 0.1 MPa and 1.0 GPa, is −0.0435 GPa–1. Its magnitude is more than twice larger than that of unsupported Au+···Au+ bonds, which means that the supported bonds are more than twice harder (deform twice less). Hence the difference between the unsupported and supported Au+···Au+ bonds diminish with pressure. At 0.1 MPa, the supported Au+···Au+ bonds are similar in length to those in metallic gold. Pressure of 1.0 GPa squeezes these supported Au+···Au+ bonds on average to the distance by 0.05 Å shorter than that in metal (Figure ), while the difference between unsupported Au+···Au+ bonds and metallic gold is reduced from 0.2 Å at 0.1 MPa to 0.1 Å.
elements.clean_text: The unsupported intermolecular Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds are compressed at the average rate of β(Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+) = (1/d)(Δd/Δp) equal to -0.1006 GPa-1. The average compressibility β(Au⋅⋅⋅Au) of intramolecular ligands-supported Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds, measured between 0.1 MPa and 1.0 GPa, is -0.0435 GPa-1. Its magnitude is more than twice larger than that of unsupported Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds, which means that the supported bonds are more than twice harder (deform twice less). Hence the difference between the unsupported and supported Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds diminish with pressure. At 0.1 MPa, the supported Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds are similar in length to those in metallic gold. Pressure of 1.0 GPa squeezes these supported Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds on average to the distance by 0.05 Å shorter than that in metal (Figure ), while the difference between unsupported Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds and metallic gold is reduced from 0.2 Å at 0.1 MPa to 0.1 Å.

elements.content: The Au8 turn of the helix in phase α is quite regular, according to two symmetry-independent Au+···Au+···Au+···Au+ torsion angles equal to −45° (Figure and Figure S1 in the ). In β-AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2, the Au16-pitch helices become less regular (Figure ). Phases α and β are centrosymmetric, and there are both left- and right-handed helices. The helical modulation can be connected with the intramolecular and intermolecular strain between the Et2DTC units. Annular S–Au–Au angles inside the AuEt2DTC monomers are between 81.4 and 95.2°. The annular torsion angles S–Au–Au-S are on average −37°, and extra-annular ones of about −63° (). The compression of phase α increases the annular S–Au–Au–S angles and decreases the extra-annular ones by about 5°. The Au+···Au+···Au+ angles are of about 171° and 177°, which illustrates the directional flexibility of Au+···Au+ bonds and their sensitivity to the crystal environment. Despite the similar structure of phases α and β, the ligands are considerably shifted, according to the changed modulation of filaments.
elements.clean_text: The Au8 turn of the helix in phase α is quite regular, according to two symmetry-independent Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ torsion angles equal to -45° (Figure  and Figure S1 in the ). In β-AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2, the Au16-pitch helices become less regular (Figure ). Phases α and β are centrosymmetric, and there are both left- and right-handed helices. The helical modulation can be connected with the intramolecular and intermolecular strain between the Et2DTC units. Annular S-Au-Au angles inside the AuEt2DTC monomers are between 81.4 and 95.2°. The annular torsion angles S-Au-Au-S are on average -37°, and extra-annular ones of about -63° (). The compression of phase α increases the annular S-Au-Au-S angles and decreases the extra-annular ones by about 5°. The Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ angles are of about 171° and 177°, which illustrates the directional flexibility of Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds and their sensitivity to the crystal environment. Despite the similar structure of phases α and β, the ligands are considerably shifted, according to the changed modulation of filaments.

elements.content: Torsion angles Au+···Au+···Au+···Au+ as a function of pressure in α-AuEt2DTC (open circles) and in β-AuEt2DTC (full circles). The dotted line indicate the torsion angle changing its handedness through 180° (solid line).
elements.clean_text: 6  Torsion angles Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ as a function of pressure in α-AuEt2DTC (open circles) and in β-AuEt2DTC (full circles). The dotted line indicate the torsion angle changing its handedness through 180° (solid line).

elements.content: This modulation change can be rationalized by increased interactions between neighboring filaments. In phase α, their helix modulation is of the opposite handedness, as illustrated in Figure . The opposite handedness of helices is unfavorable for close packing, as the threads cannot efficiently fit into the grooves running in the opposite sense. The close packing can be improved when the turns at least partly reverse their handedness, as observed in the β phase (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: This modulation change can be rationalized by increased interactions between neighboring filaments. In phase α, their helix modulation is of the opposite handedness, as illustrated in Figure . The opposite handedness of helices is unfavorable for close packing, as the threads cannot efficiently fit into the grooves running in the opposite sense. The close packing can be improved when the turns at least partly reverse their handedness, as observed in the β phase (Figure ).

elements.content: Closest filaments with their ligands mashed in the structure of AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 viewed along (left) and perpendicular to (right) their average planes in (a) phase α; and (b) phase β. The handedness of each helix is opposite to that of its four closest neighbors (cf. Figure ).
elements.clean_text: 7  Closest filaments with their ligands mashed in the structure of AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 viewed along (left) and perpendicular to (right) their average planes in (a) phase α; and (b) phase β. The handedness of each helix is opposite to that of its four closest neighbors (cf. Figure ).

elements.content: It can be concluded that at ambient conditions the Au+···Au+ bonded polymer, AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 crystallizes in forms α and β, depending on the contents (x) of solvating CH2Cl2 in the hydrophobic voids. Form α is favored by larger contents of CH2Cl2, whereas its lower content leads to phase β, with the smaller voids and the filaments around more tightly packed than in phase α. The high solvation causes a loose packing of filaments and their helical modulation in α-AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2. In the high-pressure β-form the frequency of filaments is halved and unwinding snags develop, which facilitate a tighter accommodation of helices of opposite handedness. The effect of large CH2Cl2 contents “inflating” the voids in the α-AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 can be counteracted by pressure, inducing the transition to phase β at about 50 MPa. The transition pressure value depends on the solvent-content parameter x, fixed during the synthesis and can be tuned by this parameter. Owing to this feature, AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 is an attractive material for pressure sensors, particularly as this compound is built of metallic Au+···Au+ filaments. Their modulation is, to our knowledge, the smallest-scale observation of a helix, changing its frequency and partly unwinding. These transformations can be rationalized in the terms of pressure-enhanced interactions in the crystal lattice, and also correlated with the solvate contents. In these respects, the transformations of helical filaments in AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 resemble those of DNA and RNA helices. The mother-liquor composition and high pressure are known to induce transformation between left and right-handed helices in DNA forms B and Z, respectively, and between the opposite-handedness helices in RNA forms A and Z. Several elements of the filaments transforming in AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 are consistent with the characteristic features in the mathematical model of unwinding snags describing macroscopic systems, such as climbing-plants tentacles and telephone cords. The compression of Au+···Au+ indicates that high-pressure synthesis of aurophilic complexes can lead to new compounds of ligand supported monatomic wires.
elements.clean_text: It can be concluded that at ambient conditions the Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonded polymer, AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 crystallizes in forms α and β, depending on the contents (x) of solvating CH2Cl2 in the hydrophobic voids. Form α is favored by larger contents of CH2Cl2, whereas its lower content leads to phase β, with the smaller voids and the filaments around more tightly packed than in phase α. The high solvation causes a loose packing of filaments and their helical modulation in α-AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2. In the high-pressure β-form the frequency of filaments is halved and unwinding snags develop, which facilitate a tighter accommodation of helices of opposite handedness. The effect of large CH2Cl2 contents "inflating" the voids in the α-AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 can be counteracted by pressure, inducing the transition to phase β at about 50 MPa. The transition pressure value depends on the solvent-content parameter x, fixed during the synthesis and can be tuned by this parameter. Owing to this feature, AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 is an attractive material for pressure sensors, particularly as this compound is built of metallic Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ filaments. Their modulation is, to our knowledge, the smallest-scale observation of a helix, changing its frequency and partly unwinding. These transformations can be rationalized in the terms of pressure-enhanced interactions in the crystal lattice, and also correlated with the solvate contents. In these respects, the transformations of helical filaments in AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 resemble those of DNA and RNA helices. The mother-liquor composition and high pressure are known to induce transformation between left and right-handed helices in DNA forms B and Z, respectively, and between the opposite-handedness helices in RNA forms A and Z. Several elements of the filaments transforming in AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 are consistent with the characteristic features in the mathematical model of unwinding snags describing macroscopic systems, such as climbing-plants tentacles and telephone cords. The compression of Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ indicates that high-pressure synthesis of aurophilic complexes can lead to new compounds of ligand supported monatomic wires.

elements.content: Synthesis of Sodium Diethyldithiocarbamate Trihydrate. Sodium diethyldithiocarbamate trihydrate was synthesized according to the previously described procedure. 5.15 mL of diethylamine (50 mmol) in 15 mL of methanol and 2 g of sodium hydroxide (50 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL of distilled water were mixed together in a 50 mL Erlenmeyer flask. The mixture was cooled in the ice bath and stirred. Through a dropping funnel, 3 mL (50 mmol) of carbon disulfide in 15 mL of methanol was carefully added to the mixture drop by drop. After 30 min, the pale-yellow powder precipitated. The resulting precipitate was filtered off on a Büchner funnel, washed with distilled water and left to dry. Yield 67%.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

 Synthesis of Sodium Diethyldithiocarbamate Trihydrate. Sodium diethyldithiocarbamate trihydrate was synthesized according to the previously described procedure. 5.15 mL of diethylamine (50 mmol) in 15 mL of methanol and 2 g of sodium hydroxide (50 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL of distilled water were mixed together in a 50 mL Erlenmeyer flask. The mixture was cooled in the ice bath and stirred. Through a dropping funnel, 3 mL (50 mmol) of carbon disulfide in 15 mL of methanol was carefully added to the mixture drop by drop. After 30 min, the pale-yellow powder precipitated. The resulting precipitate was filtered off on a Büchner funnel, washed with distilled water and left to dry. Yield 67%.

elements.content: Synthesis of Gold­(I) Diethyldithiocarbamate Polymer AuEt2DTC. Gold­(I) diethyldithiocarbamate polymer [Au2(C4H10NCS2)2] n was synthesized in the reaction of sodium diethyldithiocarbamate trihydrate with PPh3AuCl gold­(I) complex (from Sigma-Aldrich without further purification) in the dichloromethane/methanol (v:v/1:1) solution. 0.1 g of PPh3AuCl dissolved in 2 mL of dichloromethane was added to a 2 mL methanol solution of sodium diethyldithiocarbamate. The resulting mixture was stirred for 8 h until colorless crystals of triphenylphosphine precipitated. The precipitate was filtered off, and the solution was left for crystallization. After 1 day, needle-like orange crystals formed in the mother-liquor. They could be separated from continuously precipitating triphenylphosphine colorless crystals by picking up the selected orange crystals with a needle under an optical microscope.
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of Gold(I) Diethyldithiocarbamate Polymer AuEt2DTC. Gold(I) diethyldithiocarbamate polymer [Au2(C4H10NCS2)2] n  was synthesized in the reaction of sodium diethyldithiocarbamate trihydrate with PPh3AuCl gold(I) complex (from Sigma-Aldrich without further purification) in the dichloromethane/methanol (v:v/1:1) solution. 0.1 g of PPh3AuCl dissolved in 2 mL of dichloromethane was added to a 2 mL methanol solution of sodium diethyldithiocarbamate. The resulting mixture was stirred for 8 h until colorless crystals of triphenylphosphine precipitated. The precipitate was filtered off, and the solution was left for crystallization. After 1 day, needle-like orange crystals formed in the mother-liquor. They could be separated from continuously precipitating triphenylphosphine colorless crystals by picking up the selected orange crystals with a needle under an optical microscope.

elements.content: High-Pressure X-ray Structural Studies of AuEt2DTC. X-ray diffraction measurements of gold AuEt2DTC needle-like single crystals were performed using diffractometers KUMA KM4 and Oxford Diffraction Xcalibur Eos equipped with a CCD detector and a monochromated Mo sealed tube source (Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). For high pressure experiments a modified Merrill-Bassett diamond-anvil cell (DAC with the anvils mounted directly on the steel supports) was used. A single crystal of gold­(I) complex and a small ruby chip were glued to the culet surface of a diamond anvil. A tungsten gasket 0.1 mm thick and with 0.3 mm diameter hole was mounted. The chamber was filled with methanol used as a hydrostatic medium and closed. The DAC was centered on the diffractometer by the semiautomatic gasket-shadow procedure. The CrysAlisPro program suite was used for the data collection, UB-matrix determination and initial data reduction. Then the reflections intensities were corrected for the DAC absorption and gasket shadowing and diamond-anvil reflections were eliminated. The high pressure X-ray experiments were performed at 0.05, 0.24, 0.58, 0.90, and 1.0 GPa. Because of long unit-cell parameter c exceeding 45 Å the sample–detector distance was increased to 110 mm, which optimized the experimental conditions between X-rays absorption in air, coverage of recorded data by more distant detector and the resolution of closely located reflections. Another difficulty associated with the large lattice constants was the considerable number of densely distributed sample reflections of which many overlapped with the reflections from the diamond anvils. Hundreds of so overlapped reflections have been scrupulously eliminated. The structures were solved and refined using SHELX programs.
elements.clean_text: High-Pressure X-ray Structural Studies of AuEt2DTC. X-ray diffraction measurements of gold AuEt2DTC needle-like single crystals were performed using diffractometers KUMA KM4 and Oxford Diffraction Xcalibur Eos equipped with a CCD detector and a monochromated Mo sealed tube source (Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). For high pressure experiments a modified Merrill-Bassett diamond-anvil cell (DAC with the anvils mounted directly on the steel supports) was used. A single crystal of gold(I) complex and a small ruby chip were glued to the culet surface of a diamond anvil. A tungsten gasket 0.1 mm thick and with 0.3 mm diameter hole was mounted. The chamber was filled with methanol used as a hydrostatic medium and closed. The DAC was centered on the diffractometer by the semiautomatic gasket-shadow procedure. The CrysAlisPro program suite was used for the data collection, UB-matrix determination and initial data reduction. Then the reflections intensities were corrected for the DAC absorption and gasket shadowing and diamond-anvil reflections were eliminated. The high pressure X-ray experiments were performed at 0.05, 0.24, 0.58, 0.90, and 1.0 GPa. Because of long unit-cell parameter c exceeding 45 Å the sample-detector distance was increased to 110 mm, which optimized the experimental conditions between X-rays absorption in air, coverage of recorded data by more distant detector and the resolution of closely located reflections. Another difficulty associated with the large lattice constants was the considerable number of densely distributed sample reflections of which many overlapped with the reflections from the diamond anvils. Hundreds of so overlapped reflections have been scrupulously eliminated. The structures were solved and refined using SHELX programs.

elements.content: All H atoms were located from the molecular geometry. The atoms of CH2Cl2 units in the β structure have large thermal atomic displacement parameters (ADPs) in connection to the disorder of these weakly bonded molecules in the voids. Structural and experimental details are available free of charge in the CIF format from the Cambridge Crystallographic Database Centre (CCDC 980956–980965).
elements.clean_text: All H atoms were located from the molecular geometry. The atoms of CH2Cl2 units in the β structure have large thermal atomic displacement parameters (ADPs) in connection to the disorder of these weakly bonded molecules in the voids. Structural and experimental details are available free of charge in the CIF format from the Cambridge Crystallographic Database Centre (CCDC 980956-980965).

elements.content: CCDC 980956–980965 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for low temperature and high pressure measurements (respectively from 125 to 300 K, and from 0.0001 to 1.0 GPa) of gold­(I) diethyldithiocarbamate crystals. These data can be obtained free of charge from the CCDC via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif. PDF file showing the structural details of gold­(I) diethyldithiocarbamate crystals. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

Synthesis of Sodium Diethyldithiocarbamate Trihydrate. Sodium diethyldithiocarbamate trihydrate was synthesized according to the previously described procedure. 5.15 mL of diethylamine (50 mmol) in 15 mL of methanol and 2 g of sodium hydroxide (50 mmol) dissolved in 5 mL of distilled water were mixed together in a 50 mL Erlenmeyer flask. The mixture was cooled in the ice bath and stirred. Through a dropping funnel, 3 mL (50 mmol) of carbon disulfide in 15 mL of methanol was carefully added to the mixture drop by drop. After 30 min, the pale-yellow powder precipitated. The resulting precipitate was filtered off on a Büchner funnel, washed with distilled water and left to dry. Yield 67%.

Synthesis of Gold­(I) Diethyldithiocarbamate Polymer AuEt2DTC. Gold­(I) diethyldithiocarbamate polymer [Au2(C4H10NCS2)2] n was synthesized in the reaction of sodium diethyldithiocarbamate trihydrate with PPh3AuCl gold­(I) complex (from Sigma-Aldrich without further purification) in the dichloromethane/methanol (v:v/1:1) solution. 0.1 g of PPh3AuCl dissolved in 2 mL of dichloromethane was added to a 2 mL methanol solution of sodium diethyldithiocarbamate. The resulting mixture was stirred for 8 h until colorless crystals of triphenylphosphine precipitated. The precipitate was filtered off, and the solution was left for crystallization. After 1 day, needle-like orange crystals formed in the mother-liquor. They could be separated from continuously precipitating triphenylphosphine colorless crystals by picking up the selected orange crystals with a needle under an optical microscope.

cln_elements.content: Schematic structural formula of Au+···Au+ bonded filament in AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2. The curly brackets below the scheme indicate one of two identical units in phase α (red) and twice longer interval in phase β (blue), where two units of phase α are somewhat differentiated. The ligand-supported endocyclic Au+···Au+ bonds are by about 0.2 Å shorter than the exocyclic unsupported bonds. H-Atoms and solvate molecules have been omitted in this scheme.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic structural formula of Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonded filament in AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2. The curly brackets below the scheme indicate one of two identical units in phase α (red) and twice longer interval in phase β (blue), where two units of phase α are somewhat differentiated. The ligand-supported endocyclic Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonds are by about 0.2 Å shorter than the exocyclic unsupported bonds. H-Atoms and solvate molecules have been omitted in this scheme.

cln_elements.content: Single turns of helix-modulated Au+···Au+ bonded filaments viewed perpendicular and along their direction in phases: (a) α-AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2; (b) β-AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2. The AuEt2DTC monomer has been enclosed in brackets. The thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 30% probability level and isotropic H atoms as small spheres. The solvate molecules are omitted.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Single turns of helix-modulated Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ bonded filaments viewed perpendicular and along their direction in phases: (a) α-AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2; (b) β-AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2. The AuEt2DTC monomer has been enclosed in brackets. The thermal ellipsoids are shown at the 30% probability level and isotropic H atoms as small spheres. The solvate molecules are omitted.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 viewed perpendicular to and along the Au+···Au+ filaments: (a) phase α at 296 K/0.1 MPa; (b) phase β at 296 K/0.58 GPa. The thermal ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level. The disordered CH2Cl2 molecules have been omitted for clarity (cf. Figure S7).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure of AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 viewed perpendicular to and along the Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ filaments: (a) phase α at 296 K/0.1 MPa; (b) phase β at 296 K/0.58 GPa. The thermal ellipsoids are drawn at the 50% probability level. The disordered CH2Cl2 molecules have been omitted for clarity (cf. Figure S7).

cln_elements.content: Pressure dependence of the unit-cell dimensions in the AuEt2DTC phases α (open circles) and β (full circles): (a) molecular volume (V/Z); (b) unit-cell parameters. The dashed lines indicate the phase transition.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Pressure dependence of the unit-cell dimensions in the AuEt2DTC phases α (open circles) and β (full circles): (a) molecular volume (V/Z); (b) unit-cell parameters. The dashed lines indicate the phase transition.

cln_elements.content: Compression of Au+···Au+ distances in AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 phases α (open circles) and β (full symbols): intramolecular ligand-supported bonds are shorter, and intermolecular ligand-unsupported bonds are longer. The pressure dependence of Au···Au distance (hardly changing to 1.0 GPa) metallic gold is shown as the dashed line.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Compression of Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ distances in AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 phases α (open circles) and β (full symbols): intramolecular ligand-supported bonds are shorter, and intermolecular ligand-unsupported bonds are longer. The pressure dependence of Au⋅⋅⋅Au distance (hardly changing to 1.0 GPa) metallic gold is shown as the dashed line.

cln_elements.content: Torsion angles Au+···Au+···Au+···Au+ as a function of pressure in α-AuEt2DTC (open circles) and in β-AuEt2DTC (full circles). The dotted line indicate the torsion angle changing its handedness through 180° (solid line).
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Torsion angles Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+⋅⋅⋅Au+ as a function of pressure in α-AuEt2DTC (open circles) and in β-AuEt2DTC (full circles). The dotted line indicate the torsion angle changing its handedness through 180° (solid line).

cln_elements.content: Closest filaments with their ligands mashed in the structure of AuEt2DTC·xCH2Cl2 viewed along (left) and perpendicular to (right) their average planes in (a) phase α; and (b) phase β. The handedness of each helix is opposite to that of its four closest neighbors (cf. Figure ).
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  Closest filaments with their ligands mashed in the structure of AuEt2DTC⋅xCH2Cl2 viewed along (left) and perpendicular to (right) their average planes in (a) phase α; and (b) phase β. The handedness of each helix is opposite to that of its four closest neighbors (cf. Figure ).

metadata.title:
Unwinding
Au+···Au+ Bonded Filaments in
Ligand-Supported Gold(I) Polymer under Pressure
